question: When two aircraft are approaching head-on or approximately so and there is a danger of collision, each shall

airships.

only aircraft equipped with functioning two-way radio may operate.

question: Except for ultra-light aeroplanes, no person shall fly an aircraft in Canada unless

all of the above conditions are met.

question: No person shall attempt to fly as a flight crew member of a glider if

question: Except when taking off from or landing at an airport or military aerodrome aircraft shall not be flown over the built-up areas of any city, town or other settlement or over an open-air assembly of persons except at an altitude that will permit in the event of an emergency, the landing of the aircraft without undue hazard to persons or to property on the surface; such altitude shall not in any case be less than . . . . . above the highest obstacle within a horizontal radius of two thousand feet from the aircraft. answers: 500 feet.
1,000 feet.
2,000 feet.
3,000 feet.

question: A steady green light directed at an aircraft in flight means
answers: cleared to land.
return for landing.
cleared to base leg.
cleared for final.

question: A flashing green light directed at an aircraft in flight means
answers: cleared to land.
return for landing.
cleared to base leg.
cleared for final.

question: A steady red light or red flare directed at an aircraft in flight means
answers: cleared to land.
return for landing.
cleared to base leg.
No not Land. Continue in circuit.

question: A flashing red light directed at an aircraft in flight means
answers: cleared to land.
return for landing.
airport unsafe, do not land.
cleared for final.

question: A steady green light directed at an aircraft ready for takeoff means
answers: cleared to land.
cleared to taxi, but do not take off.

cleared to takeoff.

question: A flashing green light directed at an aircraft ready for takeoff means
answers: cleared to land.
cleared to taxi, but do not take off.

cleared to taxi, but do not take off.

cleared to takeoff.

question: A flashing red light directed at an aircraft ready for takeoff means

cleared to taxi, but do not take off.

question: A flashing white light directed at an aircraft ready for takeoff means

cleared to taxi, but do not take off.
Return to ramp or hanger.
Taxi clear of the landing area in use.

question: Blinking runway lights mean

Vehicles and pedestrans are to vacate the runway in use.
Return to ramp or hanger.

at night.

Only allowed during the hours of day light as determined on the ground.
questionSource: The British Soaring Association: Bronze Certificate Confuser

question: Any body of water, or frozen surface thereof, that is not within territorial waters of any state are called
answers: oceans.
seas.
high seas.
international waters.

question: _____ airspace is below 18,000ft ASL and _____ airspace is above 18,000ft ASL.
answers: Low-level/high-level
High-level/low-level
Mid-level/high-level
Low-level/mid-level

question: Mandatory frequency mean a _____ frequency specified in the Canada Air Pilot or the Canada Flight Supplement for the use of radio-equipped aircraft operating within an MF area.
answers: VHF
HF
LF
UHF

question: Manoeuvring area means that part of an aerodrome, other than _____, that is intended to be used for the take-off and landing of aircraft and for the movement of aircraft associated with take-off and landing.
answers: an apron
a taxiway
a runway
a hangar

question: Night means the time between the ____ of evening civil twilight and the ____ of morning civil twilight.
answers: end/beginning
beginning/beginning
end/end
beginning/end

question: Operator, in respect of an aircraft, means the person that _____
answers: has possession of the aircraft as owner, lessee or otherwise.
is the Pilot in Command during flight.
usually operates the aircraft.
has permission to operate an aircraft as obtained from the owner, lessee or otherwise.

question: A powered glider is an aeroplane that, with engines inoperative, ____
answers: has the flight characteristics of a glider.
has an L/D of more than 10:1.
is capable of stowing the engine and propellor assembly.
is defined as an ultra-light aircraft.

question: RVSM airspace or Reduced Vertical Separation Minimum airspace means airspace where a vertical separation minimum of _____ feet applies.
A closed marking means a cross-shaped marking that is ____ on runways and ____ on taxiways.
answers: white/yellow
white/white
yellow/yellow
yellow/white

question: A closed marking is a cross-shaped marking that must be visible _____ AGL above the marking.
answers: 1,000 feet
250 metres
3,000 feet
1 kilometre

question: When an aerodrome is permanently closed, the operator must
answers: remove all wind direction indicators.
place closed markings on the runways.
install red flags/cones along the boundary of unserviceable movement areas.
All of the above.

question: At night, runways need to be indicated with ____ lights on either side, and taxiways need to be indicated with ____ lights on either side.
answers: white/blue
white/white
blue/blue
blue/white

question: To act as a flight crew member, one must
answers: hold the appropriate permit/license/rating and be able to produce it while exercising those priveleges.
have a valid permit/license/rating.
hold the appropriate medical certificate.
All of the above.

question: To use one's license, one must have completed a flight review within _____ preceding the flight.
answers: 12 months
6 months
5 years
3 years

question: To carry a passenger in a glider, one must have completed at least ____ takeoffs/landings in a glider within the last ____ months.
To carry a passenger in a glider, one must have utilized the launch method that will be used for the passenger flight at least ____ time(s).
answers: three
five
four
one

question: A medical certificate for a glider pilot license is valid for ____ months after the day on which the medical exam took place.
The end of the validity period of a medical certificate is calculated from the _____ following the day on which the medical exam took place.
answers: first day of the month
last day of the month
first day of the week
last day of the week

question: A person who is _____ pregnant or has given birth in the preceeding _____ shall not exercise the privileges of a license.
answers: 30 weeks/6 weeks
6 months/1 month
20 weeks/2 weeks
1 month/4 weeks

question: The classes of controlled airspace in Canada are
answers: A, B, C, D, E, and F (special use restricted/advisory).
A, B, C, D, E,  F, and G (special use restricted/advisory).
A, B, C, D, and E (special use restricted/advisory).
None of the above.

question: The classes of un-uncontrolled airspace in Canada are
answers: E and F (special use restricted/advisory).
F and G (special use restricted/advisory).
F (special use restricted/advisory) and G.
None of the above.

question: Transponder Airspace consists of _____ as specified in the Designated Airspace Handbook.
answers: all Class A, B, and C and any Class D or E
all Class B and C and any Class D or E
all Class A, F, and G and any Class D or E
all Class B, C, and F and any Class D or E

question: _____ when the appropriate air traffic control unit is not in operation.
answers: Class C airspace becomes Class E airspace
Class A airspace becomes Class B airspace
Class D airspace becomes Class F airspace
Class F airspace becomes Class A airspace

question: At and below 18,000 ft and above 2000 ft, VFR cruising altitudes are ______ for tracks 0-179 degrees and ______ for tracks 180-359 degrees.
answers: odd thousands of feet + 500 ft/even thousands of feet + 500 ft
odd thousands of feet/even thousands of feet
even thousands of feet + 500 ft/odd thousands of feet + 500 ft
even thousands of feet/odd thousands of feet

question: Unless otherwise authorized, no pilot-in-command shall operate an aircraft at an altitude lower than _____ over an aerodrome except for landing/taking off.
answers: 500 ft

question: In controlled airspace, minimum conditions for VFR flight are
answers: visibility not less than 3 miles and distance from cloud not less than 500 ft vertically and 1 mile horizontally.
visibility not less than 2 miles and distance from cloud not less than 1000 ft vertically and 1 mile horizontally.
visibility not less than 3 miles and distance from cloud not less than 250 ft vertically and 2000 ft horizontally.
visibility not less than 1 miles and distance from cloud not less than 500 ft vertically and 2000 ft horizontally.

question: In un-controlled airspace, at or above 1000 ft AGL during day, minimum conditions for VFR flight are
answers: visibility not less than 1 miles and distance from cloud not less than 500 ft vertically and 2000 ft horizontally.
visibility not less than 2 miles and distance from cloud not less than 500 ft vertically and 1 mile horizontally.
visibility not less than 3 miles and distance from cloud not less than 250 ft vertically and 0.5 miles horizontally.
visibility not less than 1 miles and distance from cloud not less than 500 ft vertically and 1 mile horizontally.

question: If there is a 2-way radio-ommunications failure in VFR flight in Class B, C, or D airspace, the pilot-in-command shall
answers: leave the airspace, in controlled airspace by landing at the aerodrome, or else by shortest route.
set the aircraft transponder code to 7600 (if equipped).
inform an air traffic control unit as soon as possible of actions taken.
All of the above.

question: No person shall operate a glider in day VFR flight unless it is equipped with at least
answers: an altimeter, airspeed indicator, and magnetic compass.
an altimeter, airspeed indicator, and time-piece.
an altimeter, airspeed indicator, and variometer.
an altimeter and an airspeed indicator.

question: A person may activate an ELT during _____ for a duration _____ for the purpose of testing it.
answers: the first five minutes of any hour UTC/of not more than five seconds
the first two minutes of any hour UTC/of not more than five seconds
the first five minutes of any hour UTC/of not more than two seconds
the first five minutes of any odd hour UTC/of not more than five seconds

question: Where an ELT has been inadvertently activated during flight, the pilot-in-command of the aircraft shall ensure that the ELT is switched off and that
answers: the nearest ATC unit, flight service station, or aerodrome radio station is so informed ASAP.
the nearest ATC unit or Transport Canada Office is contacted immediately.
all nearby aircraft are informed of the mistake over the radio.
the ELT is never switched on by accident again.

question: Every owner of a glider must keep
answers: a journey log.
a journey log and a separate technical record.
an electronic journey log.
a technical record of each installed engine.

question: No person shall conduct a take-off in a glider unless the journey log is on board the glider unless
answers: it is not planned that the glider will land and shut down at any location other than the point of departure.
it is not planned that the glider will fly farther than 25 nm from the point of departure.
the glider does not reach an altitude above 10,000 ft ASL.
the distance between the point departure and the point of arrival is less than 25 nm.
